text:
Comprehension question on modules: When ones includes a new module by e.g. by:
`include("MyExample.jl")`
Then, why does:
`Main.MyExample` appear? Is the new module added, now living inside Main? Thanks

elements.text: Comprehension question on modules: When ones includes a new module by e.g. by:
appear? Is the new module added, now living inside Main? Thanks

text: Yes, that's right. Everything you evaluate is happening in Main, so if you include a module, it becomes a submodule of Main

elements.text: Yes, that's right. Everything you evaluate is happening in Main, so if you include a module, it becomes a submodule of Main

text: Is the `using`  command more suitable in making code inside modules available in Julia? It looks like the language expects a package however, or am I wrong?

elements.text: command more suitable in making code inside modules available in Julia? It looks like the language expects a package however, or am I wrong?

text: if you include a module and want to use that module, do `using .Module`
